segments.title: Compatibility
segments.description: Degree to which a product, system or component can exchange information with other products, systems or components, and/or perform its required functions while sharing the same common environment and resources.

segments.title: FAIRness
segments.description: FAIRness refers to the degree to which research software adheres to the FAIR principles: Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable.

segments.title: Flexibility
segments.description: Degree to which a product can be adapted to changes in its requirements, contexts of use or system environment.

segments.title: Functional Suitability
segments.description: This characteristic represents the degree to which a product or system provides functions that meet stated and implied needs when used under specified conditions.

segments.title: Interaction Capability
segments.description: This characteristic represents the degree to which a product or system supports users in performing their tasks and achieving specified goals.

segments.title: Maintainability
segments.description: This characteristic represents the degree of effectiveness and efficiency with which a product or system can be modified to improve it, correct it or adapt it to changes in environment, and in requirements.

segments.title: Performance Efficiency
segments.description: This characteristic represents the degree to which a product performs its functions within specified time and throughput parameters and is efficient in the use of resources (such as CPU, memory, storage, network devices, energy, materials...) under specified conditions.

segments.title: Reliability
segments.description: Degree to which a system, product or component performs specified functions under specified conditions for a specified period of time.

segments.title: Safety
segments.description: This characteristic represents the degree to which a product under defined conditions to avoid a state in which human life, health, property, or the environment is endangered.

segments.title: Security
segments.description: Degree to which a product or system defends against attack patterns by malicious actors and protects information and data so that persons or other products or systems have the degree of data access appropriate to their types and levels of authorization.

segments.title: Sustainability
segments.description: The capacity of the software to endure. In other words, sustainability means that the software will continue to be available in the future, on new platforms, meeting new needs.

rings.title: Research infra software
rings.description: This involves software that captures broadly accepted ideas, methods and models for use in research, warranting close researcher involvement in their development. This tier represents broadly applicable research software, often with a large and possibly distributed development team.

rings.title: Prototype tools
rings.description: This refers to research software that demonstrates a new idea, method or model for use beyond the project in which it originated, often as a substantive intellectual contribution or proof of concept. These tools are designed to answer multiple research questions and are typically developed and used by more than one person.

rings.title: Analysis code
rings.description: This involves software that captures broadly accepted ideas, methods and models for use in research, warranting close researcher involvement in their development. This tier represents broadly applicable research software, often with a large and possibly distributed development team.

labels.title: EVERSE Technology Watch - This is a development version and does not reflect EVERSE recommendations yet.
labels.footer: Preliminary work for Technology Watch(TW), developed as part of EVERSE project, referencing AOE tech radar. It is likely to be changed, it contains a collection of software quality tools and their metadata in terms of quality indicators and quality dimentions. It contains all the tools for research software quality that align, adapt, and extend to the specific needs of various research communities.
